content: The Act may be cited as the "Our Nation's Trade, Infrastructure, Mobility, and Efficiency Act of 2007" or the "ON TIME Act of 2007". The growth in international trade, especially containerized trade, is straining the nation's transportation network and contributing to traffic congestion near major U.S. international gateways. Between 2000 and 2005, the value of international trade increased from $2 trillion to $2.6 trillion, with the number of containerized trade shipments rising from 59 million to 81 million 20-foot equivalent units. The growth in international trade has led to a significant increase in freight shipments congestion. The United States is involved in multiple free trade agreements and negotiations, contributing to the rise in traffic congestion within the country. Traffic congestion in US cities is worsening, leading to Americans wasting 4.2 billion hours in traffic and buying 2.9 billion extra gallons of fuel annually, costing $78 billion. Over 200 freight bottlenecks result in $8 billion in economic losses and 243 million hours of delay each year. To maintain current transportation conditions, $235 billion was invested in 2006 by all levels of government. To improve transportation and reduce congestion, the government invested $235 billion in 2006, $304 billion in 2015, and plans to invest $472 billion in 2030. Additionally, to address major transportation needs and reduce freight congestion, a total investment of $288 billion in 2006, $368 billion in 2015, and $561 billion in 2030 is required. The government aims to reduce freight congestion and enhance transportation system reliability to improve the quality of life for US citizens. Establishment and collection of national trade gateway corridor fee. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a national trade gateway corridor fee on imported articles in the United States, amounting to .075 percent of the article's value or $500, whichever is less. The Secretary of Transportation will assess and collect a fee for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors based on the value of imported articles, as defined in the Tariff Act of 1930. Amounts received from the fee will be deposited into a designated account. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a national trade gateway corridor fee on exported articles. The fee will not apply after fiscal year 2017. The fee on exported articles from the United States will be 0.075 percent of the article's value or $500, whichever is less. The Secretary of Transportation will oversee fee collection in collaboration with the Secretary of Homeland Security. The fee for eligible transportation trade corridor projects will be assessed and collected by the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Commerce. Amounts received will be deposited in a designated account. The fee will not apply after fiscal year 2017. The "National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund" account is established in the Treasury for fees collected under this section. The account will consist of deposited amounts and will be available for expenditures by the Secretary of Transportation to meet obligations of the United States for eligible projects before October 1, 2018. SEC. 4. APPORTIONMENT OF FUNDS. The Secretary of Transportation sets aside 2 percent of funds for administrative expenses related to collecting fees on imports and exports. After this set-aside, the remaining funds are apportioned to State departments for implementing the Act. State departments of transportation receive grants for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry based on fees collected in the previous fiscal year. Fees collected for each port are compared to the total fees collected for all ports to determine the grant allocation ratio. State departments of transportation receive grants for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry based on fees collected in the previous fiscal year. The Secretary apportions funds for projects in corridors spanning multiple states based on the total lane miles of Federal-aid highways in each state. The Secretary apportions funds for projects in transportation trade corridors based on the total vehicle miles traveled on lanes on Federal-aid highways in each state, relative to the total vehicle miles traveled in all states. Amounts granted to a State department of transportation for eligible projects in a transportation trade corridor shall be available for obligation for 6 years. Unobligated funds after this period will be reallocated to other States for similar projects. The Secretary can allocate funds to States for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors. SEC. 5. PROJECT SELECTION AND ELIGIBILITY. The Secretary of Transportation must issue project selection guidelines for State departments of transportation to follow in selecting eligible projects for grants under this Act, including consulting with various stakeholders during the process. The State departments of transportation must adhere to planning processes and develop a transparent selection process for rating proposed projects for grants under the Act. The basis for rating projects must be clearly identified. The State department of transportation has developed a ratings process for projects under the Act. The State department of transportation has developed a ratings process for projects under the Act. SEC. 6. GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary of Transportation may grant funds to a State department of transportation for projects in transportation trade corridors. Grants are only for eligible projects meeting construction standards for highways on a Federal-aid system. The Federal share of funding is determined for each project. The Federal share of funding for eligible projects under this Act is 80 percent, with the non-Federal share not allowed to come from other Federal funds. Prevailing wage rates apply to projects receiving assistance under this section. The Federal share of funding for eligible projects under this Act is 80 percent, with prevailing wage rates applying to projects receiving assistance under this section. Assistance provided under this section is applied in the same manner as assistance under chapter 1 of such title. SEC. 7. TRANSPORTATION TRADE CORRIDORS. The Secretary of Transportation, with consultation from the Secretary of Commerce, will establish transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry based on specific criteria. These corridors may span multiple contiguous states but cannot exceed 300 miles from the designated port of entry. The Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, will establish transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry based on specific criteria. These corridors may span multiple contiguous states but cannot exceed 300 miles from the designated port of entry. The corridors must only include areas used for motor vehicle and cargo movements related to international trade. Additionally, a single transportation trade corridor can be established for multiple ports of entry located close to each other. The Secretary of Transportation must publish the boundaries of proposed corridors in the Federal Register within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of Transportation will establish transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry based on specific criteria. A 45-day comment period will be provided for public input on the proposed corridors, with hearings as needed. The final boundaries of the corridors must be published in the Federal Register within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Transportation will conduct periodic reviews and modifications to ensure that there is a transportation trade corridor for each Customs port of entry and that the boundaries of the corridor align with the objectives of the Act. The Secretary of Transportation will issue regulations within one year of the Act's enactment to carry out its objectives. Authorization of appropriations is also included in the Act. The National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund is authorized to receive appropriations for fiscal years 2009 through 2018. Funds deposited in the Fund can be used for highway projects, with grants approved by the Secretary considered as contractual obligations of the Government. Authorization for these funds is available for obligation on October 1 of the fiscal year. The National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund is authorized to receive appropriations for fiscal years 2009 through 2018. Eligible projects include those under chapter 1 of title 23, US Code, and construction or improvements to publicly owned intermodal freight transfer facilities. The National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund is authorized to receive appropriations for eligible projects related to transportation infrastructure modifications. Federal-aid highways and State departments of transportation are defined within the legislation. The term "State department of transportation" is defined as per section 101 of title 23, United States Code. The term "United States" refers to the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico.
